h3. Issue Summary

Bamboo pages such as the Build dashboard (allPlans.action), Build activity (currentActivity.action) and My Bamboo (myBamboo.action) are very slow to open for uses that don't have the *Admin* permission inside the _Bamboo administration > Overview > Security > Global permissions_ page.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
{panel:title=Note 1|borderStyle=dashed|borderColor=#6a8eb3|titleBGColor=#f8f8f8|bgColor=#f8f8f8}
It's important to note that this usually only affects large deployments of Bamboo (e.g. Bamboo instances with thousands or dozens of thousands of plans). If this is not your case you're likely affected by some other issue and should consider contacting [Atlassian Support|https://support.atlassian.com/] to have it verified.
{panel}
{panel:title=Note 2|borderStyle=dashed|borderColor=#6a8eb3|titleBGColor=#f8f8f8|bgColor=#f8f8f8}
The most common symptom of this issue is that the act of logging in to Bamboo is very slow for regular (non-admin) users. It is important to note that in most cases it is not the authentication process itself that is slow but loading the Build dashboard (allPlans.action) which is the page users get redirected to by default when logging in. A good way to verify whether you're affected by the problem is to ask the user to attempt to log in *and* immediately after that try to access another page inside Bamboo, such as the Projects (allProjects.action) page. If this pages loads up quickly that's a good indication that it is the Build dashboard (allPlans.action) that is slow and not the authentication process.
{panel}
 # As a regular (non-admin) user log in to Bamboo. This in itself (as explained in *Note 2*) will be slow already.
 # Once the Build dashboard (allPlans.action) comes up try to visit the Build activity (currentActivity.action) or My Bamboo (myBamboo.action) pages.

h3. Expected Results
 * Pages mentioned in this report are loading fairly quickly (e.g. just a couple of seconds).

h3. Actual Results
 * Pages are very slow to open. This is happening because Bamboo is attempting to run permission checks for all of your plans before it can display the ones that the user trying to load the page has access to. It's hard to be precise as the time will vary depending on the amount of plans we have to run permission checks for but we have seen loading times ranging from 25 seconds all the way up to minutes.

h3. Workaround

At the moment there's only one workaround available:
 # Ask the affected users to open the Build dashboard (allPlans.action).
 # Once it finishes loading click the 'pencil' icon right next to the *Personal filter is on/off* button.
 # Select the option *Show only favourite plans*.
 # Click the "Save and apply" button.

From this moment on the user will have to favourite the plans they want to see in the dashboard (otherwise it will be empty). Bamboo will stop running permission checks across all of your plans every time the user tries to load the Build dashboard (allPlans.action) or Build activity (currentActivity.action) pages. This should have a positive impact in the loading times for the pages mentioned in this report.
fields.summary: Build dashboard page slow for non admin users

h3. Issue Summary
Using Bamboo in Firefox leads to a 'missing XSRF token' error. On inspection, I find a large number of {{atl.xsrf.token}} cookies, suggesting that I'm hitting a 50 cookie limit.

The cookies differ by Path; it looks like two distinct values, with a separate copy of that cookie for around twenty different paths. That means I'm not sending them on every request, but that Bamboo can't set a new one.

h3. Environment

* Current Firefox
* Bamboo 6.10.0-m134


h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Use Bamboo, browsing to a number of different pages
 # Note that the number of cookies set accumulates
 # Note that a limit is hit, where Firefox will not pass back the cookie Bamboo is expecting.

h3. Workaround
Use Firefox's Storage Inspector to delete cookies.

h3. Problem Definition
It is only possible to create Remote Trigger based on the build plan key. If there are hundreds of plans (with multiple Linked repositories configured) in Bamboo, it is time consuming to check all the plans to implement the remote trigger for each repositories.

For example:
* PlanA use RepoA and RepoB
* PlanB use RepoB and RepoD
* PlanC use RepoA and RepoC

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be great if there is a way to perform remote trigger based on repository ID

h3. Issue Summary

1. the REST endpoint */rest/api/latest/deploy/project/\{deploymentProjectId}/versions* pagination doesn't speed up results. Projects that contain many versions can take over 40 seconds to respond.

2. The "Releases" page takes long to load and scroll through versions. */deploy/viewDeploymentProjectVersions.action*
h3. Environment

Bamboo version 6.10.0-m125 build 61004 - 20 Aug 19
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to [/rest/api/latest/deploy/project/578551811/versions?start-index=0&max-result=30|https://deployment-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/rest/api/latest/deploy/project/578551811/versions?start-index=0&max-result=30]
 # try with different max-result values and the time to respond is always the same.

h3. Expected Results

Results contain 30 releases and responds in less than 10 seconds.
h3. Actual Results

Requested versions are returned after 40 seconds
{noformat}
{ size: 4091,
  + versions: []
...
  start-index: 0,
  max-result: 30
}{noformat}
h3. Notes

Endpoint documentation doesn't say pagination is supported: [https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/REST/6.9.2/] but the page [/deploy/viewDeploymentProjectVersions.action?id=578551811|https://deployment-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/deploy/viewDeploymentProjectVersions.action?id=578551811] tries to paginate with infinite scroll using the REST call [/versions?start-index=0&max-result=30|https://deployment-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/rest/api/latest/deploy/project/578551811/versions?start-index=0&max-result=30] and that is probably the cause of taking 40 seconds to do each scroll.

The search/versions endpoint does pagination but still takes 40 seconds so it may be using the same unpaginated code in the back. e.g: [/search/versions?searchTerm=JF-PROD&chronologicalOrder=true&deploymentProjectId=578551811&start-index=0&max-result=30|https://deployment-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/rest/api/latest/search/versions?searchTerm=JF-PROD&chronologicalOrder=true&deploymentProjectId=578551811&start-index=0&max-result=30]
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behaviour. A workaround will be added here when available.
fields.summary: versions endpoint takes long to return results regardless of pagination

h3. Summary
Audit logs have the disable-enable actions shown in the wrong order.

h3. Environment
Tested in Bamboo 6.9

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Navigate to *Administration - Audit Log*.
# Disable audit logging.
# Wait at least one minute to have a different timestamp.
# Enable audit logging.

h3. Expected Results
We expect to see two entries in the audit logs. One disabling it. One enabling it.

Both entries are there, but in the wrong order. 
It should be
{noformat}
13:21, 26 Aug	mate	auditLoggingEnabled	false	true
13:21, 26 Aug	mate	auditLoggingEnabled	[true]	[false]

{noformat}
13:21, 26 Aug	mate	auditLoggingEnabled	[true]	[false]
13:21, 26 Aug	mate	auditLoggingEnabled	false	true

h3. Workaround
None

As a developer, I would like to have the option to force the creation of a tag, i.e. re-tagging, with the "Repository Tag" task.

At the moment, once a tag exists on the remote repository, recreation of the same tag fails with something like this 
{panel:title=Bamboo task log}
simple 22-Aug-2019 11:50:40 Starting task 'Tag the build as latest version' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs:task.vcs.tagging'
simple 22-Aug-2019 11:50:40 fatal: tag '"7.7"' already exists
error	22-Aug-2019 11:50:40	Error occurred while running Task 'Tag the build as latest version(5)' of type com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs:task.vcs.tagging.
error	22-Aug-2019 11:50:40	com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskException: An error occurred while tagging a repository
...
error	22-Aug-2019 11:50:40	Caused by: com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandException: command [/usr/bin/git tag "7.7" 813679c581791b975523fb4bd8de38aac91b05d0] failed with code 128. Working directory was [/app/bamboo/bamboo_agent/xml-data/build-dir/RE-CRU-JOB1]., stderr:
error	22-Aug-2019 11:50:40	fatal: tag '"7.7"' already exists

It is not possible to circumvent this limitation by manually manipulate the local / cache repository, to try removing that tag prior to (running `git tag -l 7.7` returns nothing, so `git tag -d 7.7` would have failed regardless).

Consider that a branch  "release-7.7" exists, and patch release for that "release-7.7" will be tagged as "7.7.1", "7.7.2",  etc.  For client of this artifact who simply wishes to track the latest 7.7.x they simply look at tag "7.7" and retrieve the latest "7.7".

h3. Summary

SCP Task will fail if ssh host has ed25519
h3. Environment
 - Bamboo or agent connecting via ssh to a host with ed25519 present

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 - Create a key pair using rsa.
 - Use a SCP task to connect to the host.
 - Run plan/deployment.

h3. Expected Results

Connection successful
h3. Actual Results

Bamboo will fail to create the connection
h3. Notes

The problem is related to BouncyCastle and ed25519, the error will appear even though the user doesn't use ed25519.
h3. Workaround

 

Use a script task instead with the *scp* command in it.

fields.description:
Currently, using the Docker Runner also bind-mounts the working directory (so you can easily access output artifacts from the agent host after the Docker container has exited). However, if the image you are using with the runner does not specify its own user those files are all created with UID 0 (root) which can make cleanup more complicated, as the Bamboo agent does not run as root but as its own privileged user.

What would be nice is if by default, the Docker Runner used the `--user` flag when launching the container to set the UID/GID to match the parent process, so if my agent is running as a user 'bamboo' with UID 1000 then all the files created in that bind mount have corresponding permissions.

I'm not sure if there would ever be a case where someone would want to _disable_ this functionality (so that the user specified in the Dockerfile was always used regardless of the UID/GID of the Bamboo agent). I can't think of one off the top of my head.
fields.summary: Docker Runner should inherit UID/GID from agent by default

h3. Issue Summary

When a plan branch is pointed at multiple repositories, if the branch configured on the second repository is deleted – the entire plan branch is marked for deletion even if the branch that the default repository is pointed to isn't yet deleted.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a single plan with two different repositories in Bitbucket Server
 ** *Plan Configuration >> Branches*
 *** Create plan branch: When new branch in repository is created
 *** Delete plan branch: After branch was deleted from repository 0 days
 ** *Plan Configuration >> Triggers*
 *** Replace trigger with *Repository Polling* with a 5 second interval. This poll will detect the removal of the branch eventually.
 # Manually create a new plan branch from a branch in repository one at *Plan Configuration >> Branches >> Create plan branch* E.g. develop
 # Visit the new plan branch configuration and override the branch on the *second* repository on the *Repositories tab* to one that you will delete.
 # Push a delete to the branch you just configured on the second repository:
{code:java}
git push --delete origin delbranch
git branch -d delbranch 
{code}

Now observe in Bamboo as it fails to find {{delbranch}} in the refs and marks the entire plan branch for deletion, even though its main repository points at *develop* and that is the name of the plan branch.
h3. Expected Results 

The expected behaviour is not yet defined. The plan branch should likely be disabled since a dependant branch has been removed but deleting the entire branch plan is not desirable unless both branches no longer exist (or if the branch on the default repository is removed). A disabled reason outlining why should be visible somewhere for plan administrators.

h3. Actual Results

Plan branch is marked for deletion and eventually removed.

Log snippet from atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{noformat}
2019-08-09 12:05:23,341 DEBUG [http-nio-8085-exec-17] [AccessLogFilter] END: 200 192.168.56.102 POST https://bamboo/rest/remote-event-consumer/latest/events/stash-branch-deleted-remote-event 518690kb-314kb 11ms

2019-08-09 12:05:24,944 INFO [9-BAM::PlanExec:pool-15-thread-4] [DefaultChangeDetectionManager] Found 6 open branches for ART-DEL0

2019-08-09 12:05:24,971 INFO [9-BAM::PlanExec:pool-15-thread-4] [ChainBranchManagerImpl] Chain branch ART-DEL0 was disabled because its VCS branch was deleted
2019-08-09 12:05:24,977 INFO [9-BAM::PlanExec:pool-15-thread-4] [ImmutablePlanCacheServiceImpl] Invalidating ART-DEL0

No workaround aside from disabling *Delete plan branch* at *Plan Configuration >> Branches* for the entire plan or on each important branch individually at *Branch Configuration >> Branch details tab >> Uncheck: Clean up plan branch automatically*

The below fails for BambooServer 6.9.2. In Bamboo 5.15.3, acces to AWS CodeCommit worked for Git type, authetication with username and password and thus using HTTP protocol.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Setting up a Linked repository to AWS CodeCommit of generic Git type using username & password
 # The IAM user on AWS CodeCommit side has 'AWSCodeCommitFullAccess'
 to the AWS CcodeCommit repository addresed in step 1
 # All other requirements like 'credential helper' being set and further needed AWS CodeCommit configuration is set as should

h3. Expected Results

It should be able to successfully connect to AWS CodeCommit.
h3. Actual Results

When terminating the setup of the Linked repository to AWS CodeCommitand pressing button "Test connection" on the end of this configuration page, connecting to the repository is not possible getting message pop-up saying "Fatal: Unable to access and error 403.

This happens because Bamboo inserts the username and '@' specified into the URL which AWS CodeCommit is apparently not accepting.

This is common Bamboo procedure and e.g. works perfectly like that for Bitbucket Cloud or GitHub.
h3. Notes

When running _git clone_ from command-line on the box hosting Bamboo Server, with the same username and password but without username and '@' before the AWS CodeCommit URL, things work fine. Please see below.
{noformat}
bamboo@ip-10-0-0-154:/tmp$ git clone https://git-codecommit.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/v1/repos/WTOP-Docker-build
 Cloning into 'WTOP-Docker-build'...
 Username for 'https://git-codecommit.us-east-1.amazonaws.com': bamboo-wtop-at-498104006619
 Password for 'https://bamboo-wtop-at-498104006619@git-codecommit.us-east-1.amazonaws.com': 
 remote: Counting objects: 8527, done.
 Receiving objects: 100% (8527/8527), 38.21 MiB | 6.28 MiB/s, done.
 Resolving deltas: 100% (2048/2048), done.
 Checking connectivity... done.{noformat}
Inserting the username like Bamboo Server does and running the same git clone, re-prints the same error message and errro 403 as Bamboo does when setting up the  Linked repository for AWS CodeCommit. So it fails as shown below.
{noformat}
bamboo@ip-10-0-0-154:/tmp$ git clone https://bamboo-wtop-at-498104006619@git-codecommit.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/v1/repos/WTOP-Docker-build/

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
It is not possible to secure the remote agents to connect to the Bamboo Server (using SSL) through the automatic keystore management feature.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure Bamboo to use SSL in Broker URL and Broker Client URL ([Securing your remote agents|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/securing-your-remote-agents-289277197.html])
# Restart Bamboo
# Install remote agent

h3. Expected Results
Remote agent installed and able to connect to Bamboo server successfully without problem

h3. Actual Results
Remote agent fail to connect to the SSL Broker URL
The below exception is thrown in Bamboo server atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{noformat}
2019-07-11 20:55:13,474 INFO [http-nio-8085-exec-11] [RemoteAgentManagerImpl] A remote agent is loading on localhost (127.0.0.1).
2019-07-11 20:55:16,925 WARN [ActiveMQ Transport: ssl:///127.0.0.1:54322] [Transport] Transport Connection to: tcp://127.0.0.1:54322 failed: javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: Remote host closed connection during handshake
2019-07-11 20:55:16,929 ERROR [ActiveMQ BrokerService[bamboo] Task-4] [TransportConnector] Could not accept connection from tcp://127.0.0.1:54322 : javax.net.ssl.SSLException: Connection has been shutdown: javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: Remote host closed connection during handshake
2019-07-11 20:56:09,613 ERROR [ActiveMQ BrokerService[bamboo] Task-5] [TransportConnector] Could not accept connection from tcp://127.0.0.1:54332 : javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: Received fatal alert: certificate_unknown

{noformat}

h3. Notes
The same settings works fine in Bamboo 5.14.4.1

h3. Workaround

h6. Option 1
# Edit {{$BAMBOO_HOME/bamboo.cfg.xml}}
# Add {{socket.verifyHostName=false}} to {{bamboo.jms.broker.client.uri}}. Example below:
{code}
    <property name="bamboo.jms.broker.client.uri">failover:(ssl://bamboo:54663?wireFormat.maxInactivityDuration=300000&socket.verifyHostName=false)?initialReconnectDelay=15000&maxReconnectAttempts=10</property>
{code}
# Restart Bamboo
# Restart agents

h6. Option 2
# Add the following setting into {{<remote-agent-home>/conf/wrapper.conf}}
{noformat}
wrapper.java.additional.3=-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore=<remote-agent-home>/xml-data/configuration/jmsclient.ts

{noformat}
# Restart remote agent
fields.summary: Unable to secure remote agents via automatic keystore management

h3. Issue Summary

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Setup a Bamboo build plan
 # Use e.g. a Maven builder task with e.g. 10 test cases
 # Make at least one (or more) of these test cases fail

h3. Expected Results

Independent of any test case failing or not, as the feature's description is "How many tests does your build have?" we should see the real number of existing test case and thus 10.

Even being explained by the above KB, this Report's outcome is wrong. 

A suggestion would be to run all test cases and Bamboo internall count separately tests failing, tests passing and total number of tests (basically sum of the first two ones) and display all 3 numbers in one graph (e.g. with different colors) or as of 3 parallel graphs.
h3. Workaround

The currently only known workaround is the one mentioned in the KB, namely have the build pass all test cases.

h3. Issue Summary
If a renamed user logs in before the next synchronisation, embedded Crowd will rename the user. However, it does not update Bamboo permission entries in the same way that a directory synchronisation does. 

Since the user is renamed from a Crowd perspective, the next sync won't detect a rename and permissions won't be updated at that point either.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Connect Bamboo to Active Directory (AD) and sync
# Add a specific AD user to have plan permissions
# Rename the user in AD
# Login as that user before the next syncronization

h3. Expected Results
Permissions are preserved upon rename.

h3. Actual Results
Permissions aren't preserved.

h3. Workaround
# Rename the user back to the pre-renamed username and perform a directory synchronisation at *User directories >> Synchronise*
# Rename the user back to the desired target username and perform a directory synchronisation at *User directories >> Synchronise* before the user logs in for the first time after the rename
fields.summary: Renamed user not retaining permissions if logged in before next sync

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Bamboo configuration files are updated in place when needed for both the server and remote agents. In rare cases if the update fails for reasons outside Bamboo (for example corrupted filesystem or a failed write operation) then the configuration files can be empty. This would prevent Bamboo server or agents to start.

h3. Suggested Solution

Update the configuration files on both the Bamboo server and remote agents using a copy on write approach, i.e. create a temporary config file with the updates and then rename to the original file. If the write + rename operation succeeds then the file is updated. If any of the two fails then the original configuration, before the update, is used.
This approach ensures that in all circumstances the Bamboo server and agents will have a valid configuration file.
fields.summary: Improve resilience of the Bamboo server and remote agents configuration file update

h3. Issue Summary

By default, Bamboo should use [shell interpreter |https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo-specs-docs/6.9.1/specs.html?yaml#task-script]for YAML, however, this is not the case
h3. Steps to Reproduce
{code}
version: 2
......
  tasks:     
     - script: |
        #!/bin/bash
        Hello Bamboo
{code}
h3. Expected Result

The interpreter will be chosen based on the shebang line of the script. shell (default)
h3. Actual Results

Interpreter is /bin/sh or cmd.exe
h3. Workaround

Add shell as interpreter value
{code:java}
task:
......
  - script:
     interpreter: shell
     scripts:
     - '#!/bin/bash'
     - 'ls  ${pwd}'{code}

h4. Steps to reproduce

# Create a build with 2 stages, 1 of them a final stage.
# In the first stage, add N jobs that generate an artifact.
# Each job should generate an artifact:
## Make them search for {{**/*.log}} or something.
## Untick "required".
# Create a task in the job that generates a "log" file (let's call it "job-with-no-log").
# Update one of the jobs to not output any log files at all (so that the artifact will fail to generate).
# Create a job in the final stage that will collect all of the log files from all of the artifacts and concatenate them together.
## You should use artifact subscriptions for this.
# Run the build.

h4. Expected results

The final stage's task will execute successfully when one of the configured shared artifacts is absent.

h4. Actual results

{noformat}
Failure in artifact preparation phase during processing of: Subscription for Non required shared artifact: [job-with-no-log], pattern: [**/*.log], destination: [input]
1 error(s) found when performing pre-build actions.
{noformat}

h4. My notes

* The wording of the error message in the final stage's build logs is confusing. If the artifact was "non required", why did the build fail? 
* The "Required" checkbox for artifacts states that "Build fails if the artifact cannot be published." However, the job that generates the artifact actually does fail? That's a mismatch of expectations :(

Bamboo seems to be torn between making builds fail loudly vs. allowing builds to continue when some data is absent. My expectation was that by unticking "required" on an artifact definition, any subsequent subscriptions to that artifact would work (as in, silently ignore the non-existence of it). It seems the Bamboo team's thinking does not match mine. I can appreciate that the intention is probably that builds fail if "unexpected" things happen, but this artifact is definitely optional as far as my build is concerned; it can cope just fine without it and I would expect the build to pass accordingly. 

I'd be interested in workarounds, but I'd also be keen to see the behaviour (or at least the wording) become less confusing.
fields.summary: Build failing on "Non required shared artifact"

Sequences in YAML are notably not allowed to be merged. Meanwhile, there seems to be some use-cases where having this capability would be desirable. Also, there are no workarounds in syntax that would enable sequences merging, hence the enabling of flattening sequences of sequences in post parsing would be the way to enable such syntax to work:
tasks:
  - !include multiple.tasks.in.one.file.yaml
  - !include different.task.yaml
The drawback would be the limitation of not being able to use sequences of sequences as a syntax constructor for any YAML Specs feature.
fields.summary: Allow nested sequences of tasks to work in YAML Specs
